article.headline: Mississippi 53, LSU 49
article.story: OXFORD, Miss. (AP) -- Aaron Harper scored 22 points and Mississippi won its first Southeastern Conference game by defeating LSU 53-49 on Wednesday night. Justin Reed added 16 points for the Rebels (9-6, 1-3 SEC), who limited LSU to a single field goal in the final 11 minutes of play. Harper finished 7-of-16 from the field and had a game-high five assists for the Rebels, who avoided their worst conference start since 1995 when they opened 0-5. "It was the first time that we had Justin and Aaron play well at the same time. They hit big shots when we had to have them," Ole Miss coach Rod Barnes said. "Defensively we did what we had to do down the stretch. LSU missed some shots that they normally make, but you have to give our guys credit for being in position and making it difficult for them." Jaime Lloreda had 14 points and nine rebounds for the Tigers (12-3, 2-2). The 49-point output was a season low for the Tigers. LSU has scored less than 60 points in all three losses this season. Harper hit a 3-point shot and followed with an assist for a Justin Johnson layup to give Ole Miss a 50-42 lead with 6:45 left. The Tigers missed five free throws in the final four minutes. "We were so inept offensively," said LSU coach John Brady. "We missed so many lay-ups and jumpers, it's not funny. "We did not make any significant plays to win this game. Ole Miss plays good defense and I give them a lot of credit, but we had every opportunity to win this game and we gave it away." The Tigers led only twice, both in the opening eight minutes. Ole Miss took a 15-9 lead midway through the first half on a 7-0 run. Ole Miss led 32-26 at halftime. Midway through the second half, LSU made its best run of the night, hitting 7-of-10 from the field to pull to 43-42 with 10:52 left on two free throws from Brandon Bass. But the Rebels, led by Harper, then built a 50-42 lead that proved to be insurmountable. The Rebels finished 21-of-56 from the field, but only 3-of-16 from 3-point range. The Rebels also struggled at the free throw line, hitting 8-of-13, but had only seven turnovers and dominated defensively in the final 11 minutes.
